author: Luke DeJaynes
content: Wanted to shout out @Gerhard Westphalen for recently re designing my control room.  I’d been in there 11 years and it sounds way better than ever.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I met Nile a few years ago when my boss had a writing session with him at Abbey Road studio 1. I set up a rig to continue editing vocals for a Hot Chip album in one booth, while they worked away self contained in the main control room. 

Nile had been a huge influence on my old band, and Hot Chip had been part of the soundtrack to my college years. Weird working on one on headphones while watching the other grooving away on The Hitmaker through the glass. 

It was a real “this is pretty cool” moment.

author: LAPhill
content: I propose the LWMR drinking game: When Ruairi says "trade offs," do a shot. When he says "speakers against the wall," double shot. Referencing Paris' studio build? Keg stand.

author: oaklandmatt
content: Your brain has all these wonderful ways of avoiding difficult things. This is because if you dealt with them all at once, it would overwhelm you. So the brain builds all these mechanisms and habits to help you survive. Therapy, meditation, self reflection, but most importantly *other people that you trust and can be vulnerable around* can help you get through barriers that your own brain has created

author: BatMeckley
content: Quick update for everyone: After a couple of sessions, and a good solid 2 weeks of reflection and meditation, still not finding any weakness. Just keeping you all in the loop.

author: EliHeathMusic
content: Recently switched from Spotify to Tidal and I had the same reaction. I also can't overstate how nice it is to be able to easily access extended credits AND ALSO not know how many times something has been streamed. I hadn't realized this as much in the years that I used Spotify, but as soon as I switched off of it, it became immediately apparent how much seeing the streaming metrics as the first thing had been shaping my impression of every artist or song I listened to before I even pressed play. I think the fact that Spotify hides most credits and highlights stream counts is a subtle but very real reflection of the way that the company has been turning music from an art into a commodity.

author: Slow Hand
content:
On reflection, the material benefits of *Option #1* are a nice selling point, but I think the bigger opportunity is to harness the superpower of rendering hit music at will. It would give me tremendous sway over the music industry once everyone comes to recognize that I can't miss. I would leverage that influence to make some positive changes where I can. Set up some institutions to cultivate and nurture the next generation of artists. 

Presumably, while the hit music I’m making runs counter to my personal tastes, it seems reasonable that it would still be valuable to *someone*. Just not to me. That will be my curse. I would dutifully churn out hits as fast as I am able to and gift humanity with a tsunami of unimpeachable pop awesomeness that will endure for a century. My sacrifice would be everyone else’s gain.

Counter-intuitively, by saturating the market with my personal brand of songwriting it would inspire the next generation of songwriters. Unable to compete with my torrent of sure-shot pop badness they would respond by writing new music that is the direct antithesis of my own brand of hits. With a little luck, the musical output of these writers would be exactly what I wished to hear all along.

That’s a win/win right there. I just have to suffer a bit. I choose *Option #1*.

author: cian riordan
content:
Simple answer, but probably the greatest thing I ever learned from EV is: "it's all about how much you care”. 

If any of you have spent time around him or seen his videos, it’s pretty clear that he goes deep on all of his productions… there’s no stone that’s left unturned, no excuse to not take it fully to the end zone. There were surely some parts of this that seemed exhausting during the record making process… it surely broke a lot of musicians sitting bored on the control room couch for weeks on weeks on weeks while he labored over their recordings.

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t think there is a single person that was smartest or wisest. People all have different areas they are smart in, or wise in. The most intuitive, most empathetic, most knowledgeable (in ____), etc

I don’t really know what smart means, but people that appear smart are very nuanced about the things they don’t know or understand. They can articulate what they know, they can put things together with intuition, they can develop ideas and concepts without being fed one.

My observations of people with great wisdom seem to be the people who spend great deal of time processing emotions and self reflection. And they share what they learn from the place of empathy. 

I had a guitar teacher, he never gave me “real answers” to my questions. He always told me at the end of his version of guidance and helpful tools or some joke (again not an answer)“you’ll find the answers to any questions inside you”. Which was a wtf moment to me because I wanted the answer right then and there- but I realized often times a lot of things that are not factual cannot be answered by anyone but me because even if anyone gave their own version of answer it would not be relevant to me or I wouldn’t understand any of it unless I can make sense of things myself. That was one of the greatest and live changing advice I have received in life.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nah. That's great. 

I still remember my very first studio internship where I was assisting. The owner walked me into the control room and the first thing he told me was "Rule No. 1: Don't open your fucking mouth. If you have an idea, keep it to yourself. This room is going to have enough opinions in it as is and nobody needs another idea in the mix."

He probably said it (a little) nicer than that, but the message was unambiguous.

author: Rollmottle
content: If you want to do it pro(ish), anywhere from $5k to $7.5k should get you in a respectable ballpark. You can certainly do it for less, but if you want decent, that seems around where I'd be aiming. Interface, mic, mic stand, handful of plugins, room treatment, Kalis, DAW

author: Slow Hand
content: Haha yeah. Reminds me of a story from the lapsteel player on Dylan's *Blood On the Tracks*. He was all by himself in this huge tracking room overdubbing lapsteel. After a few takes there'd be a pause while he waited for judgement from the control room. Eventually Dylan stepped out into the live room and got right up into the guy's face and said something really condescending to him about when to play. As Dylan turned away the guy describes having "nothing but contempt for Dylan in that moment" and he got super defiant and went into "Fuck you, Dylan" mode on the next take. Once the take was done he was left in silence to wonder. And as he squinted into the control room he could see everyone laughing their asses off. Apparently the whole think was a ruse by the control room to get a certain performance out of him.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@hank01564 One of the reasons LA is so dope is that there's SO much space and SO many people trying to do things. 

Could be a small room, could be a shitty neighborhood, could be poorly soundproofed. 

Could also be a real estate guy who is getting a deal (commercial real estate is in a weird place). Could be he doesn't know what he's doing and under charging. Could be a vanity project where he's not trying to make serious money. 

Could be lots of reasons. Some mean it's no good for you, some mean you get a steal.

I've had both situations in LA. Always worth exploring.

Then I checked discord and MAN did that help my state of mind. Really working on seeing the intention of the notes and being open to achieving that vision rather than taking each note as a critical reflection of my ability and taste haha.

author: LAPhill
content: Noah covered it pretty well, but I'd add some reflection - How have you acted in the past when these things come up? Are there perhaps some behavioral tweaks you can make to make this experience less difficult or more enjoyable for them? Showing that you're working on navigating this with your partner goes a hell of a lot better than an it-is-what-it-is attitude.

author: cian riordan
content: That's super fair given the circumstances of... *gestures to everything around us*. I'm lucky to be a full-time working mixer/engineer. I'm not in the stratosphere in terms of accreditation, but I'm comfortably making a healthy living, am married, have a child, and own a house. If I relied on big breaks, I'd be absolutely nowhere. 99% of my success has come from rubbing shoulders with the right people and finding opportunity that way. A night out drinking with friends leads to meeting other people who you stay in touch with. Pretty soon they'll need help with something and then off you go, that leads to the next. 75% of what I work on is smaller potatoes... most of it will never get heard, but it pays most of my salary. And the 25% of work I have that makes it through the filters has all come through connections I've made through smaller gigs. Networking is really key. And if you're a social person, it's even better as it'll help offset the time spent alone in a soundproof room, pulling your hair out over a stupid kick drum sound.

author: Slow Hand
content: Of all the studios I've worked in, my favorites are the ones that skew towards the home-y vibe. Lots of different couches and chairs to relax on. Variable lighting. Numerous stations and tables where everyone can go off, spread out, and work on their own stuff on the side. I know that's a luxury that requires a certain amount of space, but if the control room isn't set up like an arrow in which all stations are pointing forward towards the desk/speakers I find that's a big mental relief.

author: cian riordan
content: I got padded ones so the reflections get softened upon impact. I only get a soft, pillowy reflection which is nice because most the music I work on is hard AF

author: Zach Hughes
content: He believes that losing your daylight is “the deepest form of distraction,” and you may even begin “decohering.” This is when you stop making sense to yourself, because you don’t have the mental space to create a story about who you are. You become obsessed with petty goals, or dependent on simplistic signals from the outside world like retweets. You lose yourself in a cascade of distractions. You can only find your starlight and your daylight if you have sustained periods of reflection, mind-wandering, and deep thought. James has come to believe that our attention crisis is depriving us of all three of these forms of focus. We are losing our light."

author: cian riordan
content: I saw this mentioned on one of the vocal production episodes and I don't fully agree with it. If you had a perfect reflective surface that reflected back at a 180-deg angle into the null of the mic, that might be the case. But thats very rarely what happens in the real world. The cardioid pattern is shaped like a kidney and does stretch beyond the x-axis of the diaphragm, ultimately picking up lots of reflections from behind the plane of the capsule. Put a condenser microphone on a floor tom, under a cymbal and you'll hear what I mean. Or try singing into the backside of one. It sounds awful. Often, its the shittiest of the phasey reflections that get in through the back, so it's definitely worth treating. To your point, still lots of value in making sure behind the singer is treated as well as those reflections will likely be much more broadband. But given the size of this space (it small), I'd use all the help I could get in there.

author: Eric Martin
content: there is an aesthetic middle ground, there a producer and mastering engineer in MSP that are neighbors in the same building and everything in both spaces is basically all white. White walls, white acoustic treatment, everything. I can’t handle that at all.

author: cian riordan
content: Density is your friend. The heavier the wood, the less audible/tactile resonance you'll have... especially if you plan on putting your speakers on top. Worth considering integrating some sort of soft-top surface to cut down on midrange reflections from the speakers... if you're looking to go down that rabbit hole 🙂

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I got into the two screen solution doing a Movie score. The director sat in the back and watched the footage while My partner & I were focusing on the DAW screen. Now I put my Edit screen up there so im not looking down all the time. Much better on the neck. 

Also it has the added benefit of showing musicians where we are in the session- I do a lot of control room recording and it’s super informative for that. 

And for writing sessions- having the lyrics on the big screen puts us all on the same page as well. Literally and figuratively. 

Everyone has their preferences ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: ehutton21
content:
I was gonna post about this, it’s a bit sidebar to the discussion at hand, but I’ve just done a very interesting experiment. 

My ADHD is horrid so it took some time to do, but I’ve got a routine where I catalog my “best practices/new ideas/important tidbits” notes from the discord, and I keep two brief shorthand form journals: one for while I work on a project and another for reflection after it’s over. It helps me stop thinking about the work when I want to wind down. 

Its crazy too see how over the last 3-5 months of working, my mental clarity and work flow confidence improved as I had started to build a lot of the consensus tips/habits/ideas from the discord. I’ve also recorded that people seem much more pleased with my work to date.

author: Bryan DiMaio

Getting like an interface and a DAW and a mic so you can at least record something, while throwing some moving blankets and DIY stuff up builds character lol

author: Rob Domos
content: Hot take, any thin shield like this that has hard backing will make your recording sound worse.  Your goal is to get as little wall reflection as possible and thin panels with hard backing is just bringing the wall closer. I’d recommend looking into building some Gobos. Lots of info on that floating around

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve got one of those GiK ones in my booth… all thin hard surfaces aren’t equal in terms of sound transmission, and my experience with it is the frequencies low enough to make it through the padding are pretty much low enough to work around the heavily perforated backing. 

TLDR, it was useful in drying out some particular reflections in my vocal booth, and I’m glad i have it. Not the be all and end all, but has been a useful help.

author: Zack Hames

author: jantrit
content: I worked in kitchens for a long time, it allowed me to make some cash and live but also have flexibility to take music and studio jobs when they would come around. After moving to the states I found more restaurant work but kept it to only fri/sat/sun and tried to focus the rest of the week to build contacts and do studio stuff. I got super lucky with my boss who was also in the music thing and very understanding about calling out. It eventually got to the stage where I had to call out like 3 weekends in a row so I made the jump to doing the studio stuff full time. So far it’s been working out and I’ve been lucky to keep a good basis of projects, supplementing quiet periods with studio build stuff. It can be super stressful relying 100 percent on the music thing and it’s ultimately different strokes for diff folks. I’ve seen some people who get really burnt out taking music stuff that they don’t like to pay the bills and conversely I’ve seen people getting burnt out doing other stuff that’s not music getting effected in the same way. Ultimately whatever keeps ya happy and works for you is awesome, burn out is real.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
don't know the specific answer but this feels related 

fourier is likely to be the link you're looking for. it helps seperate diff musical instrument sounds into their sine/cosine waves  (harmonic spectrum) 

the physics of instruments themselves and how theyre constructed is directly related to how sound pressure creates and multiplies  the fundamental frequencies that are being played /created. if you playa g on a horn, the space, shape and material of the horn determines the specifics of the reflections which will change the timbre of an instrument (including the amount and type of harmonics). one of the reasons there's so many diff type of the same instruments

also it's above me at this point (been a while since I had to use any of this) but you can use a harmonic equation to determine the sound an instrument will make to an extent - it's a convoluted equation if I remember correctly lol.

author: LAPhill
content: I know you're joking, but what is the point of spatial audio? To immerse the listener in a world of music. To create a 3D experience. Why? We can go outside and listen to a band in a room and hear reflections all around us. But there is a chance to go deeper with spatial audio, to create something hyper-real, as much of record making has always been. Every new technology has the opportunity to enhance or detract from our experiences, and we have to meet them where they are. Maybe Atmos ain't it, but as someone who spends a lot of time in surround.. there is a feeling to immersing yourself in sound that isn't going to come from two speakers. So yes.. mixing in Atmos can very much be a part of steering the ship.

author: kidcutler
content: Always going to be tough in that tight of a space. The reflection filter is usually unnecessary, cardioid patterns nulls are pretty specifically designed to pick up what is in front of it rather than behind, so more energy should be put into the space behind the vocalist

author: cian riordan
content: In a space that small, as much absorption as you can have will help you. Do you have a bigger room to record in or do you need the isolation? You'll likely get better sonic results if you can find a room with some more volume... that will also allow you to play with position in front of the microphone. As far as the level you should record at, if you've got any half-decent mic pre than you can go into the computer pretty conservatively. Assuming you don't have a super noisy chain, there'll be plenty of headroom in a 24 bit recording to bring it up after the fact. If you're looking for numbers, I'd shoot to get things into your DAW at around -18 dBFS. Many of the plugins modeled after analog gear tend to be happier with that level (or less if you're unsure).

author: Zakhiggins
content: Unless you have a shit tonne of bass traps in a small room, your vocal will sound very muddy and will have a not nice low end. Especially if the singer is loud

author: Zakhiggins
content: Idk what your budget is, and there's definitely more professional ways of doing this, but if you want a quick fix for this without spending money then I'd reccomend just getting the most thick material thing you can find and just squashing loads of it into the corners, mattress/duvets/clothing etc will work great for this, I used to make wooden frames and stuff towels into them so they acted a bit like bass traps.. Fixed a lot of low end problems for me..

author: Slow Hand

Perhaps. I don't see why he'd would lie about something so minor and uncalled for. It seemed curious, so I figured I'd poll the room.

That said, I know Tchad Blake, in his engineering days, would place large metal plates or tubes, or other resonant objects at an angle near a mic when tracking instruments to lend a certain reflection, phasi-ness, or resonance to a sound.

author: peterlabberton
content:
My studio has one door leading to the rest of the house, which is fine—for the most part. Unfortunately, my girlfriend is just about the loudest human on the planet when it comes to, for instance, coming home from work in the evening, or making dinner, etc.. When it’s just me working alone (which is the majority of the time), I don’t care and usually take a break when she gets home anyway. But, if I’ve got clients over when she gets home, and they aren’t good friends already, it’s pretty awkward/borderline impossible to be cutting a vocal while it sounds like she’s using a chainsaw upstairs to make dinner.

Anyone have experience with replacing or soundproofing doors? The current door is flimsy and hollow-core, and my guess is replacing it with a solid wood door and sealing well around the edges will help a ton. (There’s a healthy gap at the bottom currently.) Alternately, somewhat curious about this thing: https://residential-acoustics.com/shop/soundproofing/acoustidoor/ … I have toyed with the idea of completely blocking off the door and just entering/exciting the studio through the exterior door, and one or two of these things could be a decent way to do that with an off the shelf product. (BTW, I’m in a rental.) 🤷🏻‍♂️ Any thoughts/recs greatly appreciated!

author: kidcutler
content: Sounded like a good idea reviews seem like it’s not worth it https://www.amazon.com/Residential-Acoustics-Soundproof-Blackout-Curtains/product-reviews/B01AIIH6DW

author: jantrit
content: With isolation you’re only as good as the weakest part of your system, that is to say, is the door opening the place where you notice most sound leaking? By the sounds of it yes! First things first can you change it out to a solid core door and add weather stripping and some beefed up stops all the way around? You can get special door seal kits with a droppable bottom seal that seals tight to the floor when the door shuts, although these are like 200 bucks a pop and you can get similar if not better results making something yourself. You want to start by figuring out a rough mass per square foot for your wall assembly (include drywall, stud work, insulation etc) and then bring your door up to the same mass per square foot. Solid core door, good seals all the way around and then you can even add more mass to the door with drywall or plywood. Once your door is at least the same mass per square foot as your wall assembly you’ll have to look elsewhere to gain more isolation

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. These AI's are definitely *not* thinking and I think we'll hit the limit of what machine-learning tools are capable of talking about. They're good at mimicking existing things, but they don't do anything at all approximating cause and effect, self-reflection, or abstract thought. 

I get the impression that this model is fundamentally flawed and unable to be a true general intelligence. Which I'm happy about. Cause that would be a whole other can of worms to worry over.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think that the idea of universal appeal existing in something that is so personal is fucked up. While something that everyone can admit are good or well executed; that is something I feel is somewhat absolute - at least for the era/time being. 

 That’s why I am kind of anti-pop culture. 

Culture needs decentralization and integration at the same time. Otherwise, a lot of people won’t be motivated to do a deep soul searching and reflection on who they are, therefore taking away the opportunity to fully be themselves. 

I think pop culture requires good majority to pay attention to the same thing in order for it to work. And I think it kills healthy individualism.
